CastleMiner Z.. where do I even begin? CastleMiner Z is a Voxel FPS Horror game where your only goal seems to survive or go farther from your starting point, and go progress to get higher tiers to fight the zombies with.

First of all, the graphics; They are very poor and need work, and a lot of times glitch out.

Secondly there's the Gameplay: The gameplay is decent, but get's very repetitive, with nothing much to do other than go farther away from spawn and try not to die. The guns are very unabalanced and need work aswell. For a survival game, suprisingly you don't have to eat or anything, you can literally just sit in a hole in a mountain or something and not get killed ever, and once you're aware of that it becomes very stale.

Third of all, Optimization: This game isn't optimized very well, and has laggy FPS even on good computers. The porting from Xbox 360 to PC/Steam is poor aswell and feels like they put no effort into it. Even the Xbox 360 controller buttons are still there. It's missing basic features like a ingame chat that should be there already.

Lastly, the bugs. This game has a lot of bugs, like.. a lot of bugs. How could a game be released like this? Sonic 06 all over again.  This game is okay, but needs imporvement, I wouldn't recommend it right now.

I'd recommend making this a early access game if possible, it has potential, but it feels like your not using it. It's very lacking right now. 04/10 at it's current state (1.6.3.3)

reviewText:
First off, this game needs a LOT of work. It's fun, but there's not much here. The only things that you can craft are basic building blocks from wood gathered, tools (just like the ones in Minecraft), and an assortment of guns. It's too simple! There's no need to make a crafting table in order to make better weapons, there's no form of armor, and there's no need to build a furnace to smelt the ore that you've collected during your mining adventures. I can't stress this enough. It's too simple!

Secondly, the game is really hard, despite it's simplicity. Even playing on Easy mode, the zombies would kill me in just 3 hits, which is ridiculous. To make matters worse, when you die, all of the items in your inventory are gone. Poof, vanished into thin air, so even if you manage to get back to where you were killed, you can't collect any of your stuff that you had worked so hard for. Oh, and did I mention that the zombies spawn almost right next to you? Yeah, random spawn points for ALL of the enemies, based entirely on where you are. In other words, you are the spawn point for enemies. It's really unfair, especially when they take an entire clip to kill, can run at you faster than you can run yourself, and can kill you in 3 F#$KING HITS EVEN ON EASY MODE! Oh yeah, and a Dragon will come by and F#$k your s#$t up royally every couple of days...

Which brings me to my next issue. The day/night cycle on this game is absurd. Days only last a few minutes at best, and the night lasts forever! I got into the game, was looking through the UI for the crafting and by the time I had understood how everything worked, it was night time and I was getting my face ripped off by a zombie. It's ludicrous how short the days are and how long the nights are. SERIOUSLY needs to be reworked.

Lastly, and this is just a nitpicky thing, the sensitivity is really high, and even when you adjust it, it doesn't change anything. When you're in standard view, if you twitch in any direction, you'll practicially do a 180, but when you aim down the sight, you're lucky to get the damn thing to move. It's very unpolished. Honestly, I'd stick to Minecraft if you're looking for a sandbox crafting type game, it has way more to do, the enemies are balanced and won't continually spawn right next to you, and if you die, you can at least get your stuff back (if you manage to get back to the spot where you died fast enough)

GoldeMan's (very) Lengthy Review of CastleMinerZ!
CastleMinerZ, originally on the Xbox finally comes to the PC, but how does it hold up? Not well... if I am honest.

PROS:
+ For one, there is actually  a pretty interesting gameplay idea , what you do in this game is, kind of similar with Temple Run mixed with MineCraft where you gather materials to go out further and further in the tretarous land to find the Undead dragon where the world ends. The further you go out into the world the more zombies spawn and if you and all your allies fall, you are stripped of your inventory (Not your hotbar) and are sent back to the start. The best way to explain it is Temple Run meets Minecraft, which is pretty interesting, but unfortinutley like all the other mechanics in this game are pretty half baked and or not inplemented at all, but more on that later, and if I COULD play Dragon Endurance it currently sounds quite nice.

+  The graphics  are pretty nice as of 1.7 as they have retextured every block and monster in the game, making it more like a fresh game than a dull uninspired clone which is what it looked of before. (And the sky looks fantastic at night)

+  The music is actually nice . Yes, it does come out of nowhere but it does sound nice. (My personal favorite is the song that plays when you enter the desert!)

+  A nice variety of weapons  from shotguns to lazer swords!

+  The ambiance in caves is really creepy  and nice. Yes, the sounds are pretty lacking (check the cons section) but whenever I first walked into a cave and heard the dripping of water I felt like I was not welcome. Then, I heard the rattling of the skeletons and I was scared stiff!

+  Game CAN be fun at times. Playing this game every once in a while is actually a fun time, sure after a while the difficulty really hurts me wanting to progress but it is fun either way! I even trying to livestream it every once in a while, and everytime my friend comes over this is a game we play!

CONS: (I really hate to do this but the time has come)

+  Extremley unbalanced and near impossible. What I mean by this is one zombie (which mind you dozens of them spawn) can knock you down to under half health and they are relentless with attacks, which would be cool BUT once you are near them or their body collides with your, you slow down to a crawl and you have no choice but to look around to see it hit you once and once more spawning you back and the beginning and the hours upon hours of grinding lost. Weapons are not explained well and sometimes a weapons shoots further or has better accurancy than what it should be (IE: A pistol has better aim than a RIFLE!) Gameplay/playability

Now you might be thinking that if it's a rip off, why not get minecraft. Well, there are a few things this game has over the original game it's ripping off. The most distinctive difference that everyone notices is that this game has guns that actually function well, unlike the guns that modders have been trying to put into Minecraft for years. CastleMiner Z also has challenge, like MineCraft did, but the thing is about this is that it sort of adds into the challeneg but it also takes some of the challenge out. The basic objective of Minecraft was to survive, gathering food, cook it in a stove while stocking up on coal, keeping your health high. Your main objective in MineCraft was to reach The End, defeat the Ender Dragon. In CastleMiner Z, hunger no longer applies, which already takes away half of the challenge MineCraft had and you might be saying They did this so it wasn't a complete rip off" I say "They use the same block style of MineCraft

You might be thinking that it's great to fight tons of dragons like the ender dragon tons fo times but I beg to differ. The thing that made the Ender Dragon boss battle good in MineCraft was because you could only do that once in your playthrough and you fealt really accomplished and triumphant when you defeated this dragon and destroyed all of it's crystals. With CastleMiner Z

reviewText:
First thing you will notice is it's a clear rip of Minecraft. That aside, there is an actual goal rather than boring sandbox stuff. Rather than how far underground you go, more exciting things happen the further away you get from the spawn point (Spire), measuring distance in blocks at the top right. The weapons and bullets and junk are all the same, but it's essential to make weapons and tools out of rarer materials as the zombies, skeletons, demons, and aliens get pretty hard to kill. Not to mention random dragons flying around like it's Skyrim. It's fun cranking up the difficulty and seeing how long you can hold out in a fort, or hauling your items with you as you try to reach the farthest distance you can and digging a pit at night to stay safe from the infinite swarm of zombies.

Now the cons. Not too many, most of them are a tad annoying but it takes getting used to. But dying is definitely the worst. If playing on normal difficulty or under, when you die every item that's not in your hotbar gets dropped and you appear back at spawn maybe fifty blocks away or six-thousand; just like in minecraft. But the items dissappear after a few mere seconds, so unless you died pretty close all your hard earned ores and junk will dissappear before you reach them. Though this problem is pretty much removed if you play with friends, as they can pick up your dropped junk.

Overall a pretty interesting game, definitely worth playing on a Friday night with some other losers.

reviewText: This game is fun and all, but what about mods? Still very enjoyable nonetheless. The graphics are good. The firearms are decent at the least. The bullets arc through the air, but are effective. The aliens' appearances are unique, if not amongst themselves. Every tool does exactly what it's supposed to do, though they could last a bit longer by not being damaged from every strike on whatever block, but instead being damaged from every resource mined, dug, hacked, etc. Teleporting is a very nice feature, one not many games of this genre have. I don't like being disconnected from servers, but the plus side is that I automatically get a copy of the world I was playing in, meaning I can loot everyone's stuff and grief whatever I feel has been done wrong. The ideas aren't very original, but the game makes up for it with all it's exciting features. Overall, this game is above average. Not much is wrong with it.

reviewText:
I don't really do these very often, but I felt this one was kind of a must.

To make a relatively long story shorter: I saw that a moderator (and friend) from my community was playing this game (and knowing what this game was), so I asked him why he owned it. He said it was cheap and that it was multiplayer.

Suddenly, I had an idea. Let's stream this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

I originally went to look for it, hoping it would be as cheap as it was for him (he paid like a cent I believe), but sadly it was marked back up to $4.00 USD. Given that I didn't have $4.00 USD at the time on steam, I asked some members of my community if they'd buy it for me so I could stream it with my friend. My request was quickly accepted and I was bought this game with a lovely message that I'll leave out of this review because of Steam's rules and guidelines.

After about 10 minutes on my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ internet, I had this tiny game installed. Under the assumption that we would have a short bit of autistic fun, we set out on our little adventure.

Our stream lasted about 3 hours or so in total and we actually ended up enjoying the hell out of it, if not only for the fact that it is super basic and that you don't have to think about it at all.

Pros:
- Super simple.
- Hilariously over simplified crafting.
- Hilarious death animations.
- Hours of stupid fun with friends.
- Pretty easy gameplay mixed with random occurances of moderately difficult combat (depending where you are and how far you are into your world).
- Skeletons
- Runs on literally anything.
- Hilarious animations in general.
- You can avoid almost all fall damage by jumping before you hit the ground.
- No stress involved.
- Dirt cheap.
- Probably a few more but this is all I can think of right now.

Cons:
- Awful graphics (Almost a pro for us, simply for hilarity).
- Really basic and repetitive gameplay. (Also almost a pro because you don't have to worry about ♥♥♥♥.)
- Very few enemies, just mild reskins of each.
- Very few weapons, sometimes not even reskinned.
- Glitchy at times. (I've had some issues crafting.)
- Is no longer like, a cent.
- Stamina system is borderline ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.
- Damage system has gone full ♥♥♥♥♥♥.
- A few more but nothing major that I can think of.

Over all, it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game but can quickly devolve into mindnumbing fun with friends (and trust me, you do need friends).

Rating: 6.5 / 7 out of 10.

Edit:
The game has been updated a fair bit and it's a lot more polished than it used to be. Proper resolution support and so on.
______________________

CastleMiner Z is a decently fun game, it's pretty good with friends. It doesn't take a long time to sort of 'finish' the game and get everything you want, you can probably do it in a day. But it's still really challenging and fun during that. You actually have to be on edge and think about getting a safe house as soon as you can when you make start because when nightfall comes the zombies are actually something to be scared of and worried about. The PvE challenge in this game is very considerable and it goes up insanely when you reach Hell.

This game is by no means polished - there is a lot of kinks to work out and it isn't a very high quality game.

I got it for free during a promo thing the developers were doing, but the game is cheap - it's best  to get it when it's on sale, however.

Overall, it's not really a good game, but it's decent, and okay for a few hours of fun to return to every now and then.

reviewText:
The action packed strategy game brings a whole new view on tactical combat to computer in such a way, we can’t quite remember how long ago our jaws had smashed to the ground.

The purpose of this online game is to break through the enemy’s defences and basically lay waste to their base with the help of minions. With 5 players in both sides, each player picks a hero from the character pool. Each hero has a special style of gameplay, support to help your allies or tank to beast it out and destroy your opponents with ease.

The level up and economy system is quite intriguing. Your gold slowly trickles in, but you get bonus coins if you land the last strike on an enemy hero or minion. You gain experience for every opponent that falls in your area.

You can use your coins to purchase items that heal you, replenish your mana (which is used for spells), or boost your stats so you hit harder, run faster or just generally makes you become better at ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ up. You can even combine these items to make other items and become near unstoppable. These items can even turn the tide of the battle.

One of the few negatives is that the respawn time can take a bit too long. As the game goes on, the respawn time becomes longer and when you die: you could be waiting for over two minutes before you’re brought back into the action. You can use your coins to buy yourself back into the game, if needed.

Some can find the tutorial too long, and if you’re like me (an idiot): you can get impatient, quit the tutorial, and then have to do it all over again. It does give you a lot of information on how to play the game properly and get really stuck into it, but the game also allows you to coach other players or be coached by other players. This allows friends to help each other play the game and is really the best way to play and learn. When you are coaching or being coached, you also earn bonus, out of game experience which lets you level up and receive items for your heroes.

This game is definitely worth trying out. The fact that you can get such an epic game for free is mind blowing. You can even play offline matches against bots (also a fun way to practice). We’ve even wanted more games to be like Dota. We can not stop recommending this game.

ETC Rating: 9/11

reviewText:
Base Gameplay	The gameplay isn't anything new nor creative, this game is just a shameless Minecraft rip off.
In short - this is a downgraded Minecraft that doesn't even have water in the game.
Yeah, you have guns I guess but that's where the differences end.
Some blocks are renamed and retextured but still have their functions like in Minecraft and some are completely the same with a really small amount of actually new blocks.
Not to mention how unwelcoming the game is towards newbies.
Even on easy difficulty if a zombie catches up to you - you will die in around 2-3 seconds.
On Normal difficuly it gets even harder since zombies now spawn even at day time and just 100 blocks away from spawn is the boss of the game - the dragon.
For a newbie to even survive long enough to learn what he must actually do the answer is... play without enemies.
But where is the fun in that? Exactly, there's no fun in that.

Graphics	I will be straight to the point - Graphics look like ♥♥♥♥.
The player model is way shorter than the actually POV of the model and that's very noticable if you play with a friend.
The player model is a normal human dwarf that lives in a world made of blocks... it's doesn't really fit well together.

Crafting	It's pretty much the same as Minecraft console editions, there really isn't any need for me to go that deep.


Pros.	+There are times that I had fun in these games and that was with friends, don't bother playing alone since you will get bored in around 15 minutes.
+Somewhat understandable crafting system.

Cons.	-Sub-par gameplay that's directly ripped off from Minecraft.
-Crappy graphics that look worse than Super Mario Bros. for the NES.
-Really mediocre presentation in terms of menu and the font used for the different options you can select in the menu.
-Really difficult to get into. (Atleast for me and my brother).
-Crappy animations.

Final Verdict
6.8/10
While this isn't a good game by any means, I had some fun the first 2 hours.

reviewText:
There are certain games that take inspirations and ideas presented in other games and use them to create new and interesting experiences that in their new form have considerable merit. And then there are games that make it appear that the developer isn't even trying or just attempting to cash in on an idea that is immensely popular at the moment. CastleMiner Z is an example of the latter.

A gathering and crafting game with a focus on making guns to combat the undead in a procedurally generated voxel-based world, CastleMiner Z feels like it is trying to combine Minecraft and Day Z, but fails to properly capture the essence of either. As a zombie game, CMZ will frustrate you with unpredictable and seeminly overpowered zombies that will kill you without warning and cause you to lose your inventory. As an exploration game, CMZ will feel repetitive through it's lack of variety in enemies and otherwise barren environments. And as a creative game, CMZ horribly fails since the only thing you can build are guns, ammunition, metal blocks, doors and lights.

That is not to say the game is completely bad. The graphics are pretty decent, the crafting system is very intuitive thanks to the menu interface, and it has a strong focus on guns. But if you are looking for a deep experience where you make your own progression through better gear with the creation of an architectural masterpiece on the side, you will not find it here. The game admittedly is very low priced, but as they say, you get what you pay for. If you're looking for a really good voxel-based game that allows for actual creative options and is on Steam, I would recommend Block Story instead.

This game is a mediocre Minecaft clone.

I bought this for myself and 2 other people. The first thing that happened when I played single player was me getting attacked by zombies endlessly. First things first, the zombies are horribly made. They jump like theyre on the moon and kill you in 2-3 hits, which is absurd in its own. Zombies also spawn randomly at random places, which is just frustrating in its own right. They also break blocks which makes creating a wooden house useless because its going to be molested and destroyed the first night anyway. Not to mention also that the health is just completely broken dispite it looking quite simple. If they were going to copy MC, why not just have hearts instead of a health bar that drains so damn quick. This wouldnt be a problem if armour was a thing. The early game guns are trash at best, and the late game ones I havent even gotten to try because every time I die due to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ness of the early game guns my inventory clears and theres no way to recover it. It also annoys me how day is so short, but night is so long. When I first played I just learned the game and it was already night and me getting ♥♥♥♥♥ in all my slots. It is also left out that the durability of tools in this game is non existent in the sense that pickaxes break after about 50 blocks broken and guns break after around 1500 bullets shot. The redeeming thing about this game is the multiplayer in which playing this game solo is frustrating to the point of cutting your ♥♥♥♥ off with a meat cleaver.

6.5 / 10: Needs many updates to fix problems here listed, also not mentioning the countless other ones listed in other reviews.

reviewText:
Take 80% of minecraft, 10 percent of counterstrike, 8 percent of skyrim, and 2 more percent from alot of various other games...

Throw them into unity and blend it all together, and you have...

A waste to money.

Not a single part of this is original. Literally not one.

Worlds are literally carbon copies of Minecraft ones, only there's a lighthouse to serve as a checkpoint. It's indestructible. Hell is like it is in Terraria, only you don't need to go far to get into it. Basically 50 Y levels down is a total drop into hell, pretty much. Hell has nearly no reason to exist, quite literally.

Dragons are in this from skyrim, Zombies are in this, skeletons too, that's all you'll have for enemies.
Zombies kill you in three hits, Skeletons too, Dragons do so instantly. Hit detection is literally barebones. Damage is dealt before the proper time in the animations.

This game has less content than freaking StarForge for crying out loud. Starforge atleast has 4 tiers of tools, and even weaons of different types, and 4 tiers of armors, vehicles, blocks to create your bases with, and terminals to serve as faster crafting stations and a respawn in hte form of a bed... Even chest-like containers
This game however has only 5 block types to craft, 4 tiers of tools, 4 tiers of 2 weapons, no crafting stations, 2 chest types, no armors, no vehicles.

Seriously. This game is literally Counter-Strike: Minecraft with 2% of the content, none of the mod support, no ability to make texture packs and easily install them and even swap between them... and all for the literal same price of Minecraft, or Terraria, take your pick.

This game, like Starforge is basically evidence that you can make money off of nothing but other people's hard work and that we need a Storefront Quality Control team.

Sure, there's a mode called Endurance where you don't save the world, and dying is permanent, but it serves no real purpose. It's just an obligatory Hard" difficulty.

Get Minecraft. This game

reviewText:
CastleMiner Z (Endurance Mode): How much can you accomplish with your death?

Zombies, they are back again. Shuffling, sliding, bursting into blood savagery. How will they get you? It is only a matter of time. Inevitable. A rule programed into the very fabric of these strange cosmos.


What do you have for yourself? Let’s check your belt.

You have a stone pickaxe, compass, stone pistol with matching bullets, stone knife, and some torches. What are you going to accomplish with your materials?


The process:


Make bases at about every 1000 block mark or 500 block mark. Build a highway to get back easy. You are going to fail once on a teleport and it’s going to be harder to recover if you have left yourself no infrastructure to fall back on.


Mining.

It’s slow going, but safe. I should mention that mining is the only way you can easily get back to 3100. Get to 3100, make a base. You are going to HAVE to run across hell. There is no way around or under hell. Have to go over. I typically stay around the 7-11 block mark above the bloodstone level. This is where I find the most diamond. once you hit 2100 then diamond clumps up on the lower levels. Then around 3100 it start to appear on land.

You can mine all the way to about 3200/3400 I think, but then you are slowly pushed to the surface. The bloodstone / hell threshold slowly is brought to the surface.


Desert - Dig under

Mountains dig under or through.

Frozen Hills dig under - need shovel for snow

Hell - Fortify - rush in, make a base, die.


The tele hop.

This is what you use to keep you far in the blocks. It is costly, but it’s really the only safe method of keeping you deep into the block count. Teleporters. The ace(s) up your sleeve. Drop a tele point at your base. Take another one, run as far as you can, drop it there. If you die, that’s fine. Tele back to your base. Pick up two more teles. (At this point you have 3) Drop one tele at your base. Use the tele you ran out with and got far with. As soon as you tele to your spot, drop a FRESH tele. (DON’T USE THE ONE TO YOUR BASE - THIS IS BAD AND WILL SET YOU BACK HOURS!!!)

Tips

This game is tough. It is brutal in fact. There are a lot of hard lessons that I’ve learned.

I now have a few standard practices that really help make the going easier.

Carry your bullets on your belt.

Carry your most valuable if not most two valuable resources with you at all times.

Don’t carry more than two guns, anything more is a waste of space.

Don’t carry a melee weapon, use your pick.

Don’t use lightsabers; sure, they are cool looking and make fancy noises, but they have a short shelf life and they take important resources to make.

Only have 1 or two harvesting tool on your belt. You’re not a farmer, you’re a survivor, there will be deaths. It is better to die carrying difficult to attain resources than lose them.

ONLY KILL WHAT YOU HAVE TO, RUN FROM WHAT YOU CAN

You will die, a lot, deal with it, work around the deaths. You can use death to your advantage…..

Using your death to your advantage. Each time you die, you go to a place that has both wood and sand. Before you TP back to your base, grab some resources. You will probably need sand, wood and coal at some point. Mainly for storage, torches, and teleporters. Pick some up, better to have and not need if anything.

Get to laser weapons as fast as you can, HOWEVER, diamond is still plenty OP.

Gold is a step up about stone, but will not take you the distance. I have found that gold does not suffice for the trek across hell. Those zombies are vicious and need to die faster than gold will provide.

Lasers - you can kill both aliens and satan easily with laser weapons. You can simply run from either or murder them. They take a full clip or two from the assault rifle. You can use explosives if you have a lot.

Don’t harvest in the open.

Dig a tunnel through earth and take what is given to you.

When you need bloodstone don’t take what’s in the open!

It takes 21 hits with the diamond pickaxe to extract which is a long time.

It is best to dig into the side of a cave at the base of it and then block the entry way.

harvest bloodstone in peace.

CARRY A LOT OF TORCHES AND MARK YOUR WAY WITH THEM.

You can see torches from a long ways off and help you get back to where you need to go.

Use specific formations to mark certain things.

If you go spelunking and you find diamond but don’t have the time to extract it mark it with a torch and get it later.

Zombies, skeletons, aliens, satan. Zombies come in different varieties with different behaviors; skeletons come in varieties. Aliens and satan are mele hard hitting champions.


The achievements make this game worth while.

Some of them are indeed quite hard to attain.

reviewText:
CastleMiner Z has a simple but effective gamepaly loop that channels all the excitement of crafting better tools in a way that is more comprehensive and predictable than the game it borrows from. A typical game to get to the end of the world goes something like this:

Spawn
Get underground
Start making basic tools and weapons
Survive a few nights
Get everything ready for your first expedition
Go to the surface at the start of the day and get as far as you can
Get back underground
Mine for better resources (that become more common as you get further out)
Start making better tools and resources
Make your second expedition at the start of the day
Get as far as you can
Rinse and repeat

And its fun. Simple and fun, and for only a few bucks, you're looking at several hours of gameplay. Get this game, get some friends, get some liquor, and the next time there's a dragon making a crater to get to you because you didn't get quite far enough underground and you and your friends are screaming as a horde of skeletons and zombies swarms you and your cave suddenly turns into a canyon of death, just remember that Lucky the Bear told you this game was a great idea.

reviewText: CastleMiner Z Is a great, yet hard game that has screaming sprinting zombies, yelling crazy aliens with knives for their right hand and the ever popular SPOOKY SCARY SKELETON!!! These are brutal and unforgiving yet fun to shoot in the face! the game also has some medeival elements such as dragons, lots of trees and the satisfying blacksmith hammer noise when you craft something. There are also some futuristic features such as lazer guns and swords if you ever wanted to be a jedi or storm trooper. If you don't like getting owned by the undead from the underworld, you can turn the monsters off. The game's visuals are amazing! It runs super quick even on my laptop! It still runs great even with a high visual setting. If building is more your cup of tea, then try the creative mode. I really like this game, and at such a low price the game is impossible to say no to. P.S. the game has a slight chance to slow down in the framerate department, so make sure your computer is well optimized!

reviewText:
So, to start off,This won't be a pros and cons review, just a recommendation. Please read on to see what I mean.

I only recommend this game because of it's nearly unlimited fun it contains when playing with a group of friends (At least 2-4 other people). This isn't a game I would play alone because there isn't too much to do; once you get to laser weapons and such you're pretty much done. But with friends, you tend to ignore all the cons of this unpolished indie adventure game so to speak and just enjoy exploring and slaying enemies/dragons with your friends, making the experience much more enjoyable.

Not to mention, you can get this game on the castle miner site for FREE. The only reason I see to purchase this via steam is to game with friends. To conclude, don't buy this game unless you have friends that are down for it. Besides all that, great game in my opinion, could use lots more work and updates but sadly the owners abandoned the game. Had great potential

R.I.P Castle-Miner Z 8/8 would get chased by Satan again for another $2
